title: Controlling Your iPhone from a Mac or PC: Can It Be Done?

steps.title: Update your iPhone and your Mac to the latest OS.
steps.content: Update your iPhone and your Mac to the latest OS. In order to use the iPhone Mirroring app, you’ll need to update your Mac to iOS 15 or later, and your iPhone to iOS 18 or later. [1] X Research source This new app connects your iPhone to your Mac so that you see an exact replica of your iPhone on your Mac’s screen. You can open and use apps in iPhone Mirroring just like you would on your actual phone. You’ll also need to make sure both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi are enabled on your Mac and your iPhone.

steps.title: Click the iPhone Mirroring app in the Dock.
steps.content: Click the iPhone Mirroring app in the Dock. Once you’ve updated your Mac, you should see a new icon in your Dock that looks like an iPhone screen. Click it to launch the iPhone Mirroring app. If you’re launching the app for the first time, you’ll see a screen with information about the app. Click Continue to proceed to setup.

steps.title: Unlock your iPhone.
steps.content: Unlock your iPhone. If your iPhone is locked, you’ll be prompted to unlock it before you can continue the setup process. Wait a few moments for your Mac and iPhone to connect.

steps.title: Choose if you want to allow notifications from your iPhone.
steps.content: Choose if you want to allow notifications from your iPhone. On your Mac, you’ll be prompted to choose if you want to allow notifications from your iPhone. Click Allow if you want to see iPhone notifications in your Mac’s Notification Center. This will allow your iPhone to send notifications to your Mac even when you aren’t using iPhone Mirroring.

steps.title: Click the Get Started button.
steps.content: Click the Get Started button. This button will appear once you’ve made your notification selection.

steps.title: Log in with your Mac’s administrator ID.
steps.content: Log in with your Mac’s administrator ID. When you first set up iPhone Mirroring, you’ll need to authenticate with the ID you use to log into your Mac. Enter your password or use your Mac’s Touch ID button if it has one.

steps.title: Lock your iPhone.
steps.content: Lock your iPhone. If your iPhone is still unlocked, you’ll be prompted to put it to sleep. Your iPhone must be locked for iPhone Mirroring to work. Press the side button to lock it.

steps.title: Select your authentication preferences.
steps.content: Select your authentication preferences. Next, you’ll be prompted to select whether you want to log in with your Mac’s admin ID every time you use iPhone Mirroring. If so, select Ask Every Time . If not, click Authenticate Automatically .

steps.title: Wait for your Mac and iPhone to connect.
steps.content: Wait for your Mac and iPhone to connect. After a few moments, you should see your iPhone’s screen on your Mac. You can now use your mouse and keyboard to open and interact with apps, send messages, and more! For detailed information about how to use the iPhone Mirroring interface, along with troubleshooting tips, see our full guide to iPhone Mirroring .

steps.title: Connect the iPhone to a Mac with a USB cable.
steps.content: Connect the iPhone to a Mac with a USB cable. You can use QuickTime to share your iPhone's screen to your Mac. While you won't be able to control the screen of your iPhone from your Mac, this trick can be helpful if you want to watch videos, stream content, or record your iPhone's screen from your Mac. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open QuickTime Player on your Mac.
steps.content: Open QuickTime Player on your Mac. You'll find QuickTime in your Applications list. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Press ⌥ Opt+⌘ Command+N on your Mac.
steps.content: Press ⌥ Opt + ⌘ Command + N on your Mac. This opens the New Movie Recording option. You can also get here by clicking the File menu and selecting New Movie Recording .

steps.title: Select your iPhone in QuickTime.
steps.content: Select your iPhone in QuickTime. To do this, click the down arrow next to the red Record button, and click the name of your iPhone. Once connected, you will see your iPhone's screen on your Mac. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Record your iPhone's screen (optional).
steps.content: Record your iPhone's screen (optional). If you want to record what you're doing on your iPhone while it's connected to your Mac, click the red record button in QuickTime player. When you're finished, click the Stop button to save the recording.

steps.title: Install Intel Unison on your iPhone and Windows PC.
steps.content: Install Intel Unison on your iPhone and Windows PC. If you have a PC and an iPhone, you can use Unison, a free app from Intel, to use certain functions of your iPhone in Windows. You'll be able to send and receive texts in the Messages app, view and interact with your notifications, make phone calls, and transfer files between devices. [5] X Research source Unison is available from the Microsoft Store for Windows 11. To install, visit the Intel Unison page, click Get in Store app , and follow the on-screen instructions. Unison was built to run on 13th-generation EVO Intel processors on Windows 11. It will still run on some older processors, but not all. Install Unison from the App Store on your iPhone.

steps.title: Enable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth on both your iPhone and PC.
steps.content: Enable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth on both your iPhone and PC. Unison will use both technologies to communicate. If you haven't already, enable Bluetooth on your iPhone and on your PC .

steps.title: Open Unison on your PC.
steps.content: Open Unison on your PC. When you launch Unison in Windows, you'll see a QR code. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Scan the QR code with your iPhone.
steps.content: Scan the QR code with your iPhone. Instead of using the Camera app to scan the code, you'll use the Unison app on your iPhone. Here's how: Open the Unison app on your iPhone. Provide all requested permissions when prompted. Tap Scan QR Code . Align the code in your viewfinder to scan. Click Confirm on your computer. You'll be prompted on both devices to confirm the pairing. Follow the on-screen instructions to do so. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Use Unison on your PC to control your iPhone.
steps.content: Use Unison on your PC to control your iPhone. Once your devices are paired, you can use the options in the side panel of Unison to control your iPhone. To transfer files to and from your iPhone, click File transfer . To view and manage your iPhone photos, click Gallery . To send and receive texts, click Messages . Note: You won't see your existing messages here—you'll only be able to send and receive new messages. Click Notifications to view all your iPhone's notifications. While the app is running, you'll also get your iPhone's notifications on your PC.

steps.title: Install TeamViewer on your iPhone and computer.
steps.content: Install TeamViewer on your iPhone and computer. TeamViewer is handy if you want to view an iPhone's screen remotely. The iPhone user can be anywhere in the world if they have internet access. However, you won't be able to control the iPhone remotely—you'll only be able to guide the iPhone user as they select items themselves. [8] X Research source Install the TeamViewer Quick Support app on your iPhone from the App Store . To install on your PC or Mac, go to https://www.teamviewer.com , then click Free Download at the top-right. Select your operating system and click the Download button. Double-click the downloaded file, then follow the on-screen instructions to install using the default settings.

steps.title: Create or sign in to your TeamViewer account.
steps.content: Create or sign in to your TeamViewer account. On your computer, open TeamViewer and click the Sign in button. To create a new account, click Create an account and follow the on-screen instructions to get started. You will need to add your computer to your list of trusted devices the first time you log in to TeamViewer. When you receive the "Sign on a new device" email from TeamViewer, click the Add to trusted devices button in the message.

steps.title: Open TeamViewer Quick Support on your iPhone.
steps.content: Open TeamViewer Quick Support on your iPhone. When you launch the app, you'll see "Your ID," followed by several numbers.

steps.title: On your computer, click the icon with two arrows in TeamViewer.
steps.content: On your computer, click the icon with two arrows in TeamViewer. You'll see this in the left panel of the app.

steps.title: Click Join a Session.
steps.content: Click Join a Session . It's next to "Your Sessions."

steps.title: Click Connect to a TeamViewer ID.
steps.content: Click Connect to a TeamViewer ID . You'll now see a field into which you can type a code. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Type the ID from your iPhone's screen and click Connect.
steps.content: Type the ID from your iPhone's screen and click Connect .

steps.title: Tap Allow on your iPhone's screen.
steps.content: Tap Allow on your iPhone's screen. A Screen Broadcast window will expand.

steps.title: Tap Start Broadcast.
steps.content: Tap Start Broadcast . This broadcasts your iPhone's screen to TeamViewer on your computer. The iPhone user will retain control of their screen while you're connected remotely. You won't be able to open apps or select options on their screen from your computer.

steps.title: Enable the AirPlay receiver on your Mac.
steps.content: Enable the AirPlay receiver on your Mac. You can use AirPlay to wirelessly mirror your iPhone's screen to your Mac. Note that this will allow you to see your iPhone screen, but you won’t be able to control it from your Mac. To use AirPlay, you'll need to connect both devices to the same Wi-Fi network and ensure that the devices are within Bluetooth range, as well as enable AirPlay on your Mac. Here's how: [10] X Research source Click the Apple menu and select System Settings . Click General . Click AirDrop & Handoff on the right panel. Toggle on the switch next to AirPlay Receiver . On the "Allow AirPlay for" menu, choose which devices you want to allow to connect. You can select Current User (if your iPhone and Mac are using the same Apple Account), Anyone on the Same Network (to allow any device on the Wi-Fi network to connect), or Everyone (to allow all nearby connections). Enable "Require Password," then enter a password into the field. Click OK to save.

steps.title: Open Control Center on your iPhone.
steps.content: Open Control Center on your iPhone. If your iPhone uses Face ID, swipe down from the top-right corner of the screen. If you have Touch ID, swipe up from the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Tap the Screen Mirroring icon.
steps.content: Tap the Screen Mirroring icon. It's the two overlapping squares on your iPhone's Control Center. A list of nearby devices accepting AirPlay connections will appear. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the name of your Mac.
steps.content: Tap the name of your Mac. You'll be asked to enter a password. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Enter the password to connect.
steps.content: Enter the password to connect. Once your password is accepted, you will see your iPhone's screen on your Mac. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Enable Handoff.
steps.content: Enable Handoff. You can use Handoff on your Mac and iPhone to start work on one device and then switch to another. This is a little different than controlling your iPhone from your Mac, but it can be helpful if you want to be able to edit documents you started on your iPhone when you're using your Mac (and vice-versa). You can even access your iPhone's clipboard from your Mac with Handoff. To enable Handoff: Mac: Go to Apple menu > System Settings > General > AirDrop & Handoff , then enable "Allow Handoff between this Mac and your iCloud devices." [14] X Research source iPhone: Go to Settings > General > AirPlay & Handoff (or AirPlay & Continuity , depending on your version of iOS), then turn on Handoff. Both devices will need to be signed in using the same Apple Account. [15] X Research source Bluetooth and Wi-Fi must be enabled for Handoff to work.

steps.title: Open an app that works with Handoff.
steps.content: Open an app that works with Handoff. Handoff works with Safari, Calendar, Maps, FaceTime, Mail, Reminders, Pages, Numbers, and Keynote. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Start a task in the app.
steps.content: Start a task in the app. For example, start typing in a Pages document or begin writing an email in the Mail app on either device. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Switch to your iPhone or Mac.
steps.content: Switch to your iPhone or Mac. [18] X Research source If you started the task on your Mac, you can switch to your iPhone by opening the App Switcher on your iPhone (swipe up from the bottom of the screen until you reach the middle, or double-press the Home button) and selecting From (the name of your Mac). If you started the task on your iPhone, click the app's Handoff icon on your Dock. It'll be the app's normal icon, but with a small iPhone image on it.

steps.title: Connect
steps.content: Connect your iPhone and Mac to the same Wi-Fi network. If they aren't on the same network, Switch Control won't work. Switch Control will not show your iPhone's screen on your Mac or let you use your mouse to control it. Instead, you can use this option if you use an adaptive device like a joystick or switch to move around the screen and select items, and want to use that same switch on your iPhone. [19] X Research source You must have already set up your adaptive device on your Mac for this method to work. On your iPhone , open the Settings app, tap Wi-Fi , and then tap to select the network you want to connect to. On your Mac , click the Wi-Fi icon in your menu bar, then click to select the network you're connected to on your iPhone.

steps.title: Sign in to iCloud
steps.content: Sign in to iCloud with the same Apple ID on your iPhone and Mac. Similar to the need to be on the same Wi-Fi network, your iPhone and Mac need to be signed into the same iCloud account to use Switch Control. On your iPhone, open the Settings app, and tap your name to see which iCloud account you're signed in with. If you need to switch accounts, scroll down, tap Sign Out , and sign in with a different account. On your Mac, click the Apple logo, select System Settings , then click your name at the top-left. If the Apple ID doesn't match the one you're using on your iPhone, you'll need to log out and sign in with that Apple ID. [20] X Research source To sign out, click Sign Out… at the bottom of the panel.

steps.title: Enable Switch Control on your Mac.
steps.content: Enable Switch Control on your Mac. You'll need to enable this to be able to control your iPhone with a switch on your Mac. Click the Apple logo and select System Settings > Accessibility > Switch Control . Enable "Switch Control" to show the Switch Control panel on your desktop. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Click Devices on the Switch Control panel.
steps.content: Click Devices on the Switch Control panel. It's the icon that looks like a monitor and an iPhone.

steps.title: Select your iPhone from the list.
steps.content: Select your iPhone from the list. Once you select your iPhone, you'll be able to control its screen using your adaptive switch. To stop controlling your iPhone from your Mac, click Devices on the Switch Control panel, then click Disconnect . To disable Switch Control , click the Apple logo, select System Settings > Accessibility > Switch Control and uncheck the box. [22] X Research source
